page.title: 01THE CORSE & STAUNTON AREA
page.content: Our block lies about 7 miles North West of Gloucester on the Ledbury road. The land is fairly flat, the highest point being only 60 metres above sea level. Most of the land is used for farming with dairy farming the main activity. The land drains into the Glynch Brook and then into the small River Leadon which is a tributary of the River Severn. The main area of housing is at Snigs End, lying half in Staunton and half in Corse, which is where the Chartist bungalows were built in 1848. This has become a Conservation area recently. There are few fine buildings in the villages but some of the isolated thatch cottages are of merit. Staunton Court is good example of a medieval house with later additions. The landscape near Down House is fine open typically English parkland.
